description: From Middle Dutch kronen (“to groan, lament”), from Proto-Germanic *kre-, from Proto-Indo-European *gerH- (“to cry hoarsely”).

entries.meaning: A soft or sentimental hum or song.

verbs.description: croon (third-person singular simple present croons, present participle crooning, simple past and past participle crooned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To hum or sing softly or in a sentimental manner.
examples: He was crooning a Frank Sinatra song.
He was crooning, but I couldn't make out what the song was.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To say softly or gently
examples: "Nice seeing you both," a woman at the check-in said. "Hey, I love you," another crooned.

entries.meaning: (Scotland) To make a continuous hollow moan, as cattle do when in pain.
